page.title: 08A DEFYNNOG FORGE TO A CHILD
page.content: The blacksmith's forge is dusty and dirty. In the corner of his forge he has a fire. It is hot and sweaty by the fire. He has a place where he puts the horses. The forge is a stony place, it has stone walls and stone floors. The blacksmith's forge is quiet and peaceful all you hear is the hammer on the metal or anvil. In the forge he has a cupboard for keeping his scraps of metal and horse shoes. He keeps iron in one, because people can be very fussy, and steel on another shelf. The fire is very dangerous because of all the sparks and it makes the whole room smell of smoke. Sometimes it is very steamy because of the steam which comes from the metal when it is put in water to cool and harden. (Hazel Jones)
